feed.title: Ecological and Evolutionary Genomics
feed.subtitle: The ecological and evolutionary genomics research group

entry.title: Jenny receives multiple grants!
entry.content:
Congrats to Jenny who has received not one, but two grants to fund her work on temporal seasonal adaptation in Eurytemora affinis!

The first is from Kiel Life Science and provides research funds to add more sequencing, transcriptomics, and physiology to her existing project.

The second is the Walter Benjamin Programme, which provides two years of funding to extend her current work! The phsyiological aspect of this work will be in collaboration with Meike Stumpp at CAU.

We’re excited for Jenny to uncover the genomic and physiological basis of seasonal adaptation in copepods!
entry.summary: Congrats to Jenny who has received not one, but two grants to fund her work on temporal seasonal adaptation in Eurytemora affinis!

entry.title: 2024 field collections begin
entry.content: Field collections 2024 have begun! Jenny is collecting Eurytemora copepods every two weeks over the next few months with the goal of identifying the physiological processes that are evolving across the season. As you can tell by Jenny’s field clothes, we’re still in the cold part of the year here in Kiel!
entry.summary: Field collections 2024 have begun! Jenny is collecting Eurytemora copepods every two weeks over the next few months with the goal of identifying the physiological processes that are evolving across the season. As you can tell by Jenny’s field clothes, we’re still in the cold part of the year here in Kiel!

entry.title: Gianina defends!
entry.content:
Congrats to Gianina who defended her MSc thesis!

Gianina has done lots of cool work using a long-term dataset to understand how copepod body size and abundance respond to temperature changes and if these changes can influence biomass availability in the ecosystem.

Congratulations Gianina!
entry.summary: Congrats to Gianina who defended her MSc thesis!

entry.title: Sheena graduates!
entry.content: A big congratulations to Sheena Chung, who defended her Msc thesis yesterday! We’re fortunate that Sheena will still be at GEOMAR for the next few months, but will be sad to see her leave- she has been a wonderful member of the team the past few years. But we’re sure she will go on to great things. Congratulations Sheena!
entry.summary: A big congratulations to Sheena Chung, who defended her Msc thesis yesterday! We’re fortunate that Sheena will still be at GEOMAR for the next few months, but will be sad to see her leave- she has been a wonderful member of the team the past few years. But we’re sure she will go on to great things. Congratulations Sheena!

entry.title: Halloween Party 2023!
entry.content: The lab celebrated halloween in style! Surprisingly, there was a complete lack of copepod costumes!
entry.summary: The lab celebrated halloween in style! Surprisingly, there was a complete lack of copepod costumes!

entry.title: Jenny Nascimento-Schulze joins the lab
entry.content: Jenny Nascimento-Schulze joins the group as our newest (and first!) postdoc! Jenny did her phd with at the University of Exeter with Robert Ellis working on shellfish population genetics and global change. Here she will be working on the temporal genomics of adaptation, focusing on detecting balancing and directional selection in copepods. Welcome Jenny!
entry.summary: Jenny Nascimento-Schulze joins the group as our newest (and first!) postdoc!
